Fig. 1 Powder XRD patterns recorded for pristine BMO, BMO-Na1.5, BMO-Na2.5 and Etched BMO-Na1.5. Fig. 2 XPS analysis portraying (a) survey spectrum, (b) Bi 4f, (c) Mo 3d, (d) O1s binding energies of BMO, BMO-Na0 and BMO-Na1.5. Fig. 3 SEM images of pristine BMO (a-c), BMO-Na1.5, (d-f) and (g-k) EDS spectrum and elemental mapping confirming the presence of Bi, Mo, O in BMO-Na1.5. Fig. 4 TEM images of pristine BMO (a-c) and BMO-Na1.5 (d-f). Fig. 5 (a) In situ EPR spectra and (b) Raman spectra of BMO, BMO-Na0, BMO-Na1.5 and Etched BMO-Na1.5 samples. Fig. 6 UV–vis absorption spectra of (a) series of BMO-Nax and (b) series of BMO-Ky samples. Fig. 7 Photocatalytic degradation of phenol against (a) series of BMO-Na and (b) series of BMO-K. Kinetic plots of C/C0 versus irradiation time for the photodegradation of phenol with (c) series of BMO-Na and (d) series of BMO-K. Fig. 8 Time-dependent photocatalytic H2 evolution over BMO and the BMO-Na 1.5 photocatalysts in 10 vol% aqueous methanol solution under visible-light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm). Fig. 9 (a) Photocatalytic degradation of phenol with the BMO-Na1.5 sample for five cycles. (b) XRD patterns of the BMO-Na1.5 samples before and after the photodegradation test for four cycles. Fig. 10 (a) Room-temperature PL profile and, (b) Time-resolved PL profile recorded for BMO-Na1.5 in reference to pristine BMO. Fig. 11 Photocatalytic degradation efficiencies of BMO-Na1.5 photocatalyst for photo-degradation of phenol in presence of various scavenger. Fig. 12 Spin-trapping ESR spectra for (a) BMO DMPO- O2 – (b) BMO DMPO- OH (c) BMO-Na1.5 DMPO- O2 – and, (d) BMO-Na1.5 DMPO- OH. Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Chemical Reaction Engineering College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yan’an University Yan’an 716000 China Graphical abstract A novel direct Z-scheme Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 nanocomposite was successfully obtained via simple alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 succeeded by air calcination approach, which exhibited excellent visible-light-driven photocatalytic degradation of phenol and hydrogen evolution reaction due to the direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism. This Z-scheme system not only greatly promoting the efficient separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, but also preserves strong and continuous redox ability, resulting in the very high photocatalytic performance. Semiconductor based photocatalytic technology has attracted substantial research attention based on its potential to overcome environmental and energy crisis. The conventional photocatalysts with their issues such as rapid charge recombination are considered unfavorable candidates for practical applications. Herein, a novel direct Z-scheme based photocatalyst composed of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 hetrojunction is proposed for efficient photo-degradation of phenol and hydrogen (H2) production reaction. The hetrojunction comprises of ultra-thin (2D) Bi2O3 nanosheets, in-situ grown over 3D Bi2MoO6 microspheres via simple alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 succeeded by air calcination step. The relative mass ratio of Bi2O3 and Bi2MoO6 could be fine-tuned by controlling the alkali dosage (i.e. NaOH or KOH). Unlike the conventional Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 hetrojunction, the proposed catalyst follow a direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism which permits superior photocatalytic activity with 96.4% phenol degradation efficiency and high hydrogen evolution rate of 52 μmol·g−1 under visible light irradiation. The exuberant performance is accredited to the spatially separated redox charge carriers, excellent light harvesting capability and fast-charge transportation characteristics of the proposed photocatalyst. The present work serves as a primary pathway to design and develop efficient Bi2MoO6-based direct Z-scheme photocatalysts with promising applications in environmental remediation and solar fuel production. Keywords Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst Z-scheme mechanism Electron-hole separation Photocatalytic degradation Hydrogen evolution 1 Introduction Semiconductor-based photocatalysis has proven to be a promising avenue to address the ever-growing energy and environmental issues [1–3]. The capability of a photocatalyst to directly utilize solar energy to stimulate chemical reactions and generate applicable energy has led to the advancement of various technologies including solar cells and photoelectrochemical cells. A major challenge in utilizing the full-potential of semiconductor based photocatalysts is to inhibit charge-carrier recombination while maintaining good compatibility between strong redox ability and light response window [4,5]. Among various materials, the aurivillius oxides particularly, Bi2MoO6 is widely known for its non-toxic nature and visible light photo-activity [6,7]. Bi2MoO6 based on its narrow band gap (2.4–2.8 eV) and layered structure has shown tremendous potential in areas such as CO2 reduction [8], water oxidation [9], Li-ion batteries [10], H2 production [11] and organic pollutant degradation [12]. However, the efficiency of this single component photo-catalyst is restricted due to rapid charge carrier recombination and slow charge transportation [13]. To achieve this synergistic combination, various strategies including morphology control [14], cationic or anionic doping [15,16], noble metal modifying [17] and heterojunction construction [18,19] have been explored. Among many, the heterojunction structures are known for their superior performance owing to their merits in separating charge carriers while consolidating the properties of each component [20]. To achieve an optimum performance, the design of photo-catalyst in terms of light harvesting, separated redox active sites and sustained redox capability is highly crucial. Thus, the rational selection and design of semiconducting materials in heterojunction structure is a key feature. To overcome these issues, Bi2MoO6 is often coupled with other metal oxides to construct an efficient heterojunction system. In this context, the direct Z-scheme based heterojunctions are known to exhibit superior photocatalytic characteristics compared to their conventional partners [21,22]. This distinctly different charge carrier transfer mode not only successfully inhibits carrier recombination, but also induce spatially oriented redox active sites with well-preserved redox potential, assuring high photocatalytic performance. Although, Bi2MoO6 has been coupled with verity of materials to construct an efficient Z-scheme heterojunction [11,23–25], there is however, a relentless quest to reach a more superior combination. Among the coherent materials, bismuth oxide (Bi2O3), a direct band gap (2.8 eV) semiconductor is widely considered for its performance in photo-remediation of organic pollutants [26,27]. To date, various combinations including Bi2O3/Bi2SiO5, Bi2O3/Bi2WO6 and Bi2O3/BiVO4 [28–30] have been engineered to further improve Bi2O3 photocatalytic performance. Since, the morphology of a semiconductor plays a vital role in defining its photocatalytic activity, thus 2D materials with large interfacial contact area are known to exhibit superior photo-catalytic activity compared to their customary counter-parts [31–33]. The 2D geometrical features are not only beneficial in improving charge-transfer characteristics but also shorten the charge-diffusion pathways subsequently enhancing the redox ability of the photo-catalyst under construction [34,35]. Therefore, designing a heterojunction system with optimum photocatalytic activity in addition to direct Z-scheme charge transfer mode would not only contribute in exploring superior combinations but also be a step onward to practical implementations. In this study, we attempt to produce a novel direct Z-scheme based photocatalyst composed of ultra-thin (2D) Bi2O3 and (3D) Bi2MoO6 nanostructures. The photocatalyst was prepared via simple alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 to achieve in-situ growth of 2D Bi2O3 sheets followed by calcination. The proposed method enables 3D Bi2MoO6 to act as substrate for in-situ growth of Bi2O3 sheets thereby facilitating close contact and minimizing aggregation. Unlike the conventional Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction, the designed system is based on complementary performance of each component with direct Z-scheme charge carrier transfer mode that enables superior photocatalytic activity when tested for photo-degradation of phenol and hydrogen evolution reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Sample preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Bi2MoO6 (BMO) All the chemicals were analytical grade and used without any further purification. The pristine Bi2MoO6 material was synthesized in accordance to our previous report [36]. In a typical experimental procedure, 1.3 mmol of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O and 0.65 mmol of Na2MoO4·2H2O were allowed to vortex in 13.0 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) until complete homogenization was achieved. To this, 32.5 mL of ethanol was added and solution was set to stir for 30 min. Finally, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave followed by solvothermal treatment at 160 ℃ for 12 h. At the completion of reaction, the formed precipitates were collected by simple filtration, succeeded by washing with ethanol and de-ionized water, respectively, and dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. 2.1.2 Synthesis of direct Z-scheme based Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst The Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst was synthesized using in-situ alkali treatment of BMO powder succeeded by calcination step. Herein, the BMO serves as a 3D substrate that provides active nucleation site for in-situ growth of 2D Bi2O3 sheets. In a typical experiment, 0.305 g of BMO powder was dispersed in 50 mL of dilute alkali solution with different concentration i.e. NaOH and KOH (0, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5 wt%). The prepared mixtures were then allowed to stir for 2 h at ambient air conditions prior to overnight drying at 80 ℃ to obtain precipitates. The samples were then subjected to air calcination in the muffle furnace set at 250 ℃ for 2 h with ramp rate of 10 ℃ min−1 for phase transformation. Thereafter, the samples were thoroughly washed with distilled water to remove residual alkali ions and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The prepared samples were denoted as BMO-Nax and BMO-Ky (where x and y = 0, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5), respectively. For reference, alkali etched Bi2MoO6 samples without the calcination step were also prepared. These samples were denoted as Etched BMO-Na1.5 and Etched BMO-K1.5. For comparison, α-Bi2O3 was also prepared according to the literature reported [37]. 2.2 Characterization The crystal structure and purity of the prepared material was confirmed using X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Shimadzu XRD-7000) with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) radiation with scanning rate of 2° min−1 and 2θ range of 10°–80°. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher K-Alpha) was used to evaluate surface binding energies of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst. The morphology and microstructural features were recorded using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7610F) equipped with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, X-Max-50) to assess materials elemental purity. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM and HRTEM, JEM-2100F) was employed to study morphological features, and crystal structure of the samples. The in-situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were obtained using an Endor spectrometer (Japan JEOL, JES-FA300) at 110 K. The electron spin resonance (ESR) signals was recorded using JES-FA300 model spectrometer (ESR, Japan JEOL) under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 420 nm). The magnetic central field intensity, scanning width, scanning time, and microwave power are 324.006 mT, 10.00 mT, 60 s and 0.99800 mW, respectively. In a typical experiment, 20 mg of photocatalyst was dispersed in 5 mL of ultrapure water under ultrasonic for 30 min. Then, 30 μL of 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) (30 ppm) was added with ultrasonic dispersion for 5 min. Finally, the obtained mixture (20 μL) was sampled by a capillary tube and placed into a quartz nuclear magnetic tube then subjected to test on a electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer. The signals were collected after visible light irradiation for different. The Raman Spectra were recorded using a micro Raman spectrometer (Raman, Horiba Jobin-Yvon LabRam HR800) with laser excitation set at 320 nm. The optical characteristics and band gap energies were estimated using UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis-DRS, Shimadzu UV-2550), with BaSO4 taken as reference material. Room-temperature photoluminescence spectra (PL) studies were carried using fluorescence spectrometer (PL, Hitachi F-4500) with an excitation wavelength of 400 nm. Charge carrier separation was studied using time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy (TR-PL, Edinburgh instrument FLSP920) with emission wavelength of 480 nm. Gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890 II) with a TCD detector was used to evaluate the produced H2 during photocatalytic reaction. 2.3 Photocatalytic performance 2.3.1 Photocatalytic degradation of phenol The photocatalytic activities of the photo-active materials were evaluated against photo-degradation of phenol, which is a colorless organic pollutant. The photocatalytic degradation experiments were carried in photocatalytic reactor (XPA-7) with a 400 W halogen lamp fixed with a 420 nm cut-off filter. In a typical measurement, 20 mg of the photocatalyst was dispersed in 250 mL fresh aqueous phenol solution (10 mg·L−1) for 30 min under dark conditions to establish an adsorption/desorption equilibrium. To monitor the progress of photocatalytic degradation, a 5.0 mL aliquot was separated at regular intervals of 30 min followed by high speed centrifugation to remove solid photocatalyst. The actual phenol concentration was determined using 4-aminoantipyrine assisted colorimetric method. Total organic carbon analyzer (Vario TOC, Elemental, Germany) was employed for the mineralization degree analysis of phenol. 2.3.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction was carried in a top-irradiation vessel apparatus connected to a glass circulation system. To simulate solar energy, a 300 W Xenon lamp (CEL-PE300L-3A) with 1.5AM filter was used as a visible light source. In a typical procedure, 50 mg of each photocatalyst was dispersed in a mixture containing 50 mL H2O and 5 mL methanol. A Pt co-catalyst was then deposited on the surface of photocatalysts using in-situ photo-deposition approach with H2PtCl6 taken as the precursor (nominal Pt loading 1 wt%). Prior to irradiation, the reaction system was purged with N2 gas for 30 min to remove O2, thereafter the system was sealed with rubber septum. The temperature of the system was maintained using an external flow of cooling water through glass circulation system whereas the evolved H2 gas was quantified using gas chromatograph fitted with a TCD detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst The formation mechanism of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst is schematically illustrated in Scheme 1 . Herein, BMO was prepared using a facile solvothermal approach. The formed 3D BMO nanostructures were then subjected to post-synthesis alkali treatment succeeded by air calcination to achieve in-situ growth of 2D Bi2O3 sheets. Interestingly, BMO in this case serves as an active substrate with active nucleation sites for in-situ growth of Bi2O3 subsequent to alkali etching [38]. Since, MoO3 is readily soluble in alkaline solution, post-synthesis alkali treatment of BMO would result in surface precipitation of Bi2O2 2+ layers while MoO4 2− at the surface of BMO would solubilize [35]. The formed Bi2O2 2+ layers would eventually reconstruct to a metastable Bi2O3 phase which after calcination step convert to the α-Bi2O3 phase [39,40]. This in-situ growth approach with BMO as a substrate not only suffice for Bi2O2 2+ ions but also encourages close contact between Bi2O3 and Bi2MoO6, which then assist in faster charge transportation and enhanced the photo-activity of designed heterojunction. The crystal structures of the as-synthesized BMO and its hybrid counterparts were studied using XRD. The XRD patterns were evaluated in reference to pristine BMO and series of BMO-Na powders (Fig. 1 ). The XRD pattern recorded for pristine BMO consists of peak indexed to orthorhombic crystal structure (JCPDS card No. 76-2388). The characteristic diffraction peaks of Bi2O3 were well indexed to tetragonal phase of Bi2O3 as referenced against JCPDS card No. 74-1374 [37] (see supplementary data, Fig. S1a). The XRD patterns of alkali treated BMO powders were noted to exhibit new diffraction peaks at 30.33°, 37.62°, 47.15° and 55.58°. These peaks were indexed to tetragonal phase of Bi2O3. The emergence of these peaks were evident of Bi2O3 formation at the surface of BMO. In addition, gradual rise in the peak intensities for Bi2O3 were also noted with increase in mass ratio of alkali solution i.e. NaOH/BMO (0–2.5 wt%) (see supplementary data, Fig. S1b). The surface elemental composition and chemical states were investigated using XPS analysis. Fig. 2 a shows the full survey spectrum recorded for representative BMO-Na1.5 in comparison to pristine and BMO-Na0 sample. The overlaid spectrums consists of binding energies belonging to Bi, Mo and O elements. Fig. 2b shows the high resolution deconvolute spectra’s for Bi 4f energy levels. The two representative peaks attributed to Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 for BMO were noted at 159.02 and 164.33 eV, respectively [41]. However, slightly shift in binding energies ca. 0.06 eV of the corresponding peaks were found in case of BMO-Na0. This shift is likely due to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies on the surface BMO-Na0 [7]. In case of BMO-Na1.5, a slightly larger shift of 0.10 eV was evident for the 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 peaks. This not only confirmed the existence of Bi3+ but presence of excessive surface oxygen vacancies in BMO-Na1.5. Fig. 2c shows XPS spectra of Mo 3d. The two peaks at 232.26 and 235.39 eV could be assigned to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 energy levels of BMO, respectively. The respective peaks have slightly shift towards lower binding energies of 232.11 and 235.24 eV, in case of BMO-Na1.5 which might be due to the Mo-O bond distortion [42]. Additionally, the O1s peak for BMO was deconvoluted into two peaks at 529.84 and 530.40 eV, which correspond to oxygen in Bi-O and Mo-O, respectively (Fig. 2d). The O1s binding energies for BMO-Na1.5 consists of slightly negatively shifted peaks attributed to the formation of neighboring oxygen vacancies with a high electron-attracting effect [43]. Table S1 summarizes the semiquantitative analysis of the Bi: Mo: O ratios. The result reveal that the content of Mo decreasing after alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 succeeded by air calcination step, which attributed to the solubilization of MoO4 2− at the surface of BMO [35]. The morphology and microscopic structures of the as-prepared samples were assessed using SEM, TEM and HRTEM. Fig. 3 a–c is evident of BMO’s typical hierarchical microsphere-like structure with average diameter of 1–2 μm. The microspheres consists of self-assembled nanosheets with an average thickness in range of 20–50 nm. In case of BMO-Na1.5, formation of ultra-thin transparent Bi2O3 nanosheets with random growth distribution could be seen over the surface of BMO microspheres (Fig. 3d–f). This confirms the in-situ growth and successful formation of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction. The Etched BMO-Na1.5 (see supplementary data, Fig. S2a-2c) also depicts formation of irregular nanosheets over BMO microsphere. The BMO-K1.5 shown in Fig. S2d-2f also exhibit morphological features similar to BMO-Na1.5. It is important to mention here, that use of in-situ growth strategy for Bi2O3 had negligible effect on the morphology of BMO microspheres. Moreover, the EDS elemental analysis and layer mapping shown as Fig. 3g–k confirms the presence of Bi, O and Mo as constituent elements present in BMO-Na1.5. The TEM analysis of pristine BMO further confirms its hierarchical microsphere like structures (Fig. 4 ). As clearly shown in Fig. 4a and b, pure BMO exhibited a hierarchical microsphere structure. The high resolution image (Fig. 4c) corresponds to the lattice spacing of 0.315 nm which is attributed to (1 3 1) planes of the orthorhombic BMO structure [44]. In case of BMO-Na1.5 (Fig. 4d–f) growth of ultra-thin transparent Bi2O3 nanosheets over BMO is evident. The interplanar spacing for BMO-Na1.5 were estimated to be 0.315 nm and 0.331 nm, which correspond to the (1 3 1) planes of orthorhombic BMO structures and (1 1 1) planes of Bi2O3 [35], respectively. In the heterogeneous photocatalysis, EPR measurements were performed to produce fingerprint evidences for the presence of oxygen vacancies. Generally speaking, EPR signal at g factor approximately 2.004 is attributed to free electrons capturing by surface oxygen vacancies [45]. Unlike pristine BMO, the BMO-Na1.5 exhibits a relatively strong and sharp EPR signal (g ∼ 2.004) which is typical signal of surface oxygen vacancies (Fig. 5 a). Additionally, Raman spectroscopy was carried to further investigated oxygen vacancies on the surface of base-treated sample, such as BMO-Na1.5 sample. Fig. 5b shows the Raman spectra for BMO and its hybrid counterparts. The characteristic Raman bands in range of 700–850 cm−1 and 230–460 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of MoO6 octahedra, and bending vibrations of the MoO6 octahedra and BiO3 tetrahedra respectively [46,47]. Despite similar Raman band characteristics, the peak intensities were noted to differ significantly. The relatively weak peak intensities observed for BMO-Na1.5 compared to pristine BMO imply increased surface oxygen vacancies [48]. Thus, it is safe to state that the surface oxygen vacancies could successfully be induced on the Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction using the in-situ alkali treatment of BMO substrate. The optical characteristics are highly crucial in defining practical applicability of a photocatalyst. Thus, UV–Vis diffuse reflection spectra (DRS) were recorded for BMO and its hybrid heterojunctions. Unlike the pristine BMO, which has an absorption edge near 470 nm, the heterojunctions (BMO-Na and BMO-K) display narrow absorption in the visible region (Fig. 6 a and b). Moreover, decline in visible light absorption was noted with increasing mass ratio of NaOH or KOH (see supplementary data, Fig. S3). This decline response could be the consequence of integrating a broader band gap material (Bi2O3) with BMO [35]. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity The visible-light photocatalytic performance of BMO and its hybrid heterojunctions were assessed by monitoring their capability towards degradation of phenol. As evident from Fig. 7 a, the pristine BMO possesses relatively weak photocatalytic degradation efficiency (3.2% in 180 min) compared to Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunctions. In contrast, BMO-Na1.5 exhibited the highest degradation efficiency compared to other counterparts (see supplementary data, Fig. S4a). Interestingly, the degradation efficiency were found to increase with increase mass ratio of NaOH used for synthesis (see supplementary data, Fig. S4). The optimum mass ratio of NaOH amount is 1.5 wt% and further increasing the mass ratio of NaOH results in a deterioration of activity, which may be ascribed to the formation of recombination sites by excess Bi2O3 on the surface of Bi2MoO6 and the light-shielding effect of Bi2O3 [36]. Kinetic model were fitted to understand the degradation kinetics of phenol. As seen from Fig. 7c, the phenol degradation follows pseudo-first-order kinetics with kapp values estimated to be 1.94 × 10−4, 22.40 × 10−4, 145.80 × 10−4 and 9.24 × 10−4 min−1 for pure BMO, BMO-Na0, BMO-Na1.5 and Etched BMO-Na1.5, respectively (see supplementary data, Fig. S4b). The BMO-Na1.5 displays the highest kapp value which is 75 folds higher than the value estimated for BMO. This signifies the excellent performance of the designed heterojunction. Table S2 summarizes the estimated kapp value for the photocatalysts used in the degradation of phenol. The variation of photodegradation efficiency against calcination time of BMO-Na1.5 was also studied. Fig. S4c shows a trend of increased degradation efficiency with respect to calcination time. This incremental trend could be ascribed to the accelerated charge-transportation process supported by Bi2O3 ultra-thin sheets. To understand the role of anion in enhancing photo-catalytic capability of designed material, photocatalytic degradation experiments were also carried with BMO-Ky (y = 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5) (Fig. 7b, d and see supplementary data, Fig. S4d). Fig. 7b and d is evident that optimum performance was achieved with BMO-K1.5, which is consistent with BMO-Na1.5. Thus, it is safe to assume that discreet Na ions cannot promote the photo-reaction, and existence of OH– along with its high alkalinity is crucial for Bi2O3 phase transformation which subsequently enhances the photocatalytic degradation of phenol. Furthermore, the TOC analysis was used to evaluate the mineralization degree of phenol over BMO and BMO-Na1.5 under visible light irradiation (Fig. S5). It revealed that approximately 3% of TOC were eliminated over BMO, while the BMO-Na1.5 sample achieved approximately 75.5% TOC removal efficiency within 180 min, which is in accordance with the decolorization result as shown in Fig. 7. The visible-light photocatalytic H2 evolution was studied in aqueous methanol solution. Fig. 8 shows the hydrogen production rate of BMO-Na 1.5 in comparison to pristine BMO. Unlike the pristine BMO where hydrogen production rate of 0.904 μmol·g−1·h−1 was achieved, BMO-Na 1.5 demonstrated a 14.5 fold rate increment for hydrogen production (12.97 μmol·g−1·h−1). This superior photo-catalytic performance is ascribed to the synergic combination of ultra-thin 2D Bi2O3 with BMO, creating an efficient heterojunction with minimum electron-hole recombination and faster charge-transportation. The photochemical stability and durability were also studied for the representative BMO-Na1.5 photocatalyst. Fig. 9 a shows the photocatalytic performance of BMO-Na1.5 consequently after four successive photocatalytic experiments. The slight variation in the efficiency of BMO-Na1.5, indicates the inherent long-term usage stability. The XRD patterns recorded for BMO-Na1.5 (Fig. 9b) before and after photocatalytic experiment produced no peaks which might indicate surface passivation or changes. This further confirms the photo-stability of the designed material during long-term photo-catalytic process. 3.3 Photocatalytic mechanism To understand the underlying excitation, migration and separation of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, PL spectroscopic analysis was carried for BMO-Na1.5. As seen in Fig. 10 a, BMO-Na1.5 exhibits a declined PL response compared to pristine BMO which confirms the effective separation of photo-generated charge-carriers [49]. This was further supported by time-resolved PL measurements (Fig. 10b), where BMO-Na1.5 was noted to have longer charge carriers lifetime of 1.56 ns compared to 1.26 ns estimated for pristine BMO. Table S3 summarizes the lifetime of charge carriers estimated from spectral graphs shown in Fig. 10a after fitting with double exponential function [50]. The longer lifetime in case of BMO-Na1.5 proves the successful separation of redox-active species, which in turn substantiates the formation of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction. To confirm the charge transfer mechanism in BMO-Na1.5, trapping experiments were carried for active species during the photo-catalytic degradation of phenol. Here, benzoquinone (BQ), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt (EDTA-2Na) and isopropanol (IPA) were used as scavenger for superoxide radicals ( O2 –), holes (h+) and hydroxyl radicals (·OH), respectively. As seen in Fig. 11 , the addition of BQ and EDTA-2Na significantly inhibited the degradation efficiency, while IPA had a medium effect. This concluded that the O2 −, h+ and OH radicals participated in the photocatalytic degradation where the order of the influence was determined to be O2 − > h+ > OH. The formation of active radicals was further confirmed using ESR spin-trapping experiment. Compared to pristine BMO (Fig. 12 a and b) where relatively weak signals were observed for O2 – and OH radicals, the BMO-Na1.5 produced pronounced four-line ESR signal, typical of DMPO- O2 – adduct with relative intensities of 1:1:1:1 (Fig. 12c) [51]. Similarly, a four-line ESR signal with relative intensities of 1:2:2:1 was also recorded for OH generation (Fig. 12d) [52,53]. The ESR study confirms the formation and utilization of O2 – and OH as active radicals that participated in the photo-catalytic degradation of phenol. To the best of our knowledge, the Z-scheme mechanism can be confirmed by several ways, including: (i) active radicals detection [54], (ii) in situ XPS evaluation [55] and (iii) selective photo-deposition of noble metal [56]. Based on the detailed experimentation, we argue that the photo-catalytic process over Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 is a direct Z-scheme process (Scheme 2 ). It is known that Bi2O3 possess CB and VB potential of 0.34 V and 3.14 V respectively [27]. In our case, the BMO was noted to possess CB and VB potential of −0.53 V and 1.95 V (see supplementary data, Fig. S6), which after introduction of surface oxygen vacancies could induce surface oxygen vacancies states (SOVs) with a shift to −0.53 V and 1.81 V, respectively [36]. This bandgap changes results in well-match staggered type-II heterojunction between BMO and ultra-thin Bi2O3 nanosheets [34–36]. Now, in case of heterojunction charge-transfer system the electrons in the CB of BMO will generally transfer to the CB of Bi2O3. Simultaneously, the holes in the VB of Bi2O3 will move to the VB of BMO [34,35]. However, as portrayed in Scheme 2a the excited electrons in the CB of Bi2O3 would have no ability to reduce O2 to form O2 – radicals because of relatively positive CB potential of Bi2O3 (0.33 V vs. NHE) compared to O2/ O2 − (−0.33 V vs. NHE) [57]. While the holes in the VB of BMO would become incapable of oxidizing OH− or H2O to produce OH based on negative VB potential of BMO (1.81 V vs. NHE) than OH−/ OH (2.40 V vs. NHE) and H2O/ OH (2.72 V vs. NHE) (Scheme 2a1) [58,59]. Moreover, the excited electrons in the CB of Bi2O3 would not reduce H+ to form H2 because of the relatively positive CB potential of Bi2O3 (0.33 V vs. NHE) than H+/H2 (0 V vs. NHE) (Scheme 2a2) [60]. Since, the trapping and ESR experiments were suggestive of O2 −, h+ and ·OH as predominant active species during the photocatalytic degradation of phenol, it could be preliminarily deduced that the charge separation and transfer process over proposed photocatalyst follows a direct Z-scheme mechanism. As illustrated in Scheme 2b, the coupling of ultra-thin 2D Bi2O3 nanosheets and BMO under visible light irradiation would generate substantial electron-hole pairs. The presence of SOVs over VB of BMO would promote the electron transfer from CB of Bi2O3 and combine with holes in VB of BMO (surface oxygen vacancy states) via the direct solid-solid contact interface [21]. These oxygen vacancy states would then act as an electron mediator. A similar types of oxygen vacancy and Z-scheme mechanism have been reported. Ding et al. reported Z-scheme BiO1-xBr/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst with rich oxygen vacancies and improved the visible light photocatalytic efficiency [61]. It is commonly accepted that Fermi lever is closed to the CB and VB for n-type and p-type semiconductor, respectively. Now that Bi2MoO6 is n-type semiconductor and Bi2O3 is p-type semiconductor, in theory the Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 composite can form direct Z-scheme heterojunction because the former has lower Fermi level than the latter [62–64]. This direct Z-scheme mechanism would thus result in electron accumulation in the CB of BMO and the holes in the VB of Bi2O3, spatially separating the redox-active species with strong redox ability [3,21,65]. In case of photocatalytic degradation of phenol, the electron in CB of BMO would be trapped by dissolved oxygen thereby generating O2 − radicals that further oxidize phenol directly or indirectly via production of OH [66]. Meanwhile, the holes in VB of Bi2O3 could also directly contribute towards oxidation of phenol or oxidize H2O to form ·OH radicals (Scheme 2b1). In case of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, the electrons accumulated over CB of BMO would react with water molecules to produce hydrogen whereas the photo-generated holes would contribute towards oxidation of sacrificial agents (Scheme 2b2). In view of the elaborate experimentation, it is safe to establish that Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction follows direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism and thus demonstrates exuberant photocatalytic performance during photo-catalytic degradation of phenol and photocatalytic H2 production. 4 Conclusion In summary, we propose synthesis of novel direct Z-scheme based photocatalyst composed of ultra-thin (2D) Bi2O3 and 3D Bi2MoO6 microspheres. The catalyst was synthesized using simple in-situ alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 succeeded by calcination step to obtain Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 composites. Here, the 3D Bi2MoO6 microspheres acted as a substrate for in-situ growth of Bi2O3 sheets which based on their 2D morphological characteristics contributed towards enhanced charge-carrier transportation. The relative mass ratio of Bi2O3 and Bi2MoO6 could be fine-tuned by controlling the alkali dosage (i.e. NaOH or KOH). The 1.5% Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 was determined to be the optimum ratio with superior photocatalytic performance when tested for degradation of phenol and hydrogen production. Unlike the conventional Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction, the designed system was determined to follow direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism which resulted in superior photocatalytic activity with 96.4% degradation efficiency observed for phenol and hydrogen evolution rate of 52 μmol·g−1 under visible light irradiation. The exuberant performance of the designed photo-catalyst was attributed to the spatially separated redox charge carriers, excellent light harvesting capability and fast-charge transportation characteristics of the direct Z-scheme based Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 heterojunction. The present work serves a step forward to fabricate highly active Bi2MoO6-based direct Z-scheme photocatalysts with promising applications in environmental remediation and solar fuel synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Semiconductor based photocatalytic technology has attracted substantial research attention based on its potential to overcome environmental and energy crisis. The conventional photocatalysts with their issues such as rapid charge recombination are considered unfavorable candidates for practical applications. Herein, a novel direct Z-scheme based photocatalyst composed of Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 hetrojunction is proposed for efficient photo-degradation of phenol and hydrogen (H2) production reaction. The hetrojunction comprises of ultra-thin (2D) Bi2O3 nanosheets, in-situ grown over 3D Bi2MoO6 microspheres via simple alkali treatment of Bi2MoO6 succeeded by air calcination step. The relative mass ratio of Bi2O3 and Bi2MoO6 could be fine-tuned by controlling the alkali dosage (i.e. NaOH or KOH). Unlike the conventional Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 hetrojunction, the proposed catalyst follow a direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism which permits superior photocatalytic activity with 96.4% phenol degradation efficiency and high hydrogen evolution rate of 52 μmol·g−1 under visible light irradiation. The exuberant performance is accredited to the spatially separated redox charge carriers, excellent light harvesting capability and fast-charge transportation characteristics of the proposed photocatalyst. The present work serves as a primary pathway to design and develop efficient Bi2MoO6-based direct Z-scheme photocatalysts with promising applications in environmental remediation and solar fuel production.
coredata.dc:title: Alkali-assisted synthesis of direct Z-scheme based Bi2O3/Bi2MoO6 photocatalyst for highly efficient photocatalytic degradation of phenol and hydrogen evolution reaction
